Corma, V. Forn6s, M.I. Juan-Rajadell, J.M. L6pez Nieto* Instituto de Tecnolog{a Quhnica, U.P. V.-C.S.L C., Universidad Polit~cnica, Camino de Vera s/n. 46071 Valencia, Spain Received 12 January 1994; revised 28 March 1994; accepted 28 March 1994 Abstract SO]-/ZrO2 samples were prepared by impregnation of hydrous zirconium oxides with 0.5 M H2SO 4 solutions. It was found that the pH of precipitation of the precursor Zr(OH)n has a strong influence on the structure of crystalline ZrO2 and on the catalytic properties of the sol-/ZrO2 for the isomerization of n-butane. The nature and strength of acid sites in SOl-/ZrO2 samples were studied by infrared spectra of absorbed pyridine and by temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of ammonia. Acidity and catalytic results have been compared with those obtained on an acid zeolite as H-Mordenite. It has been found that infrared spectra of pyridine can not be used for the determination of the superacid character of SOl-/ZrO2. However, the NH3-TPD technique shown that in the case of SOl-/ZrO2 samples there are superacid sites in which the NH3-desorption peak appears at about 815 K. A correlation between the number of those superacid sites and the activity for the isomerization of n-butane has been observed. Keywords: Catalyst characterization (1R/TPD); Preparation; Solid superacids; Sulfate doped zirconia; Temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia 1. Introduction Sulfated metal oxides of the superacid type present interesting catalytic properties for various carbonium ion type reactions [1-5]. In this way, sulfated zirconia shows high activity and selectivity for the skeletal isomerization of alkanes at low reaction temperatures [ 1-4,6-11 ]. It has been found [8] that superacid sites are formed during the sulfation of the oxide, regardless of the source of sulfur, i.e., *Corresponding author. Fax. However, more research needs to be carried out in order to improve the knowledge of two aspects of these materials. The first one is the systematic study of each one of the catalyst preparation steps going from the formation of the most adequate source for ZrOz up to the final sulfated form [ 9- 14]. The second aspect involves developing characterization techniques for meas- uring adequately the acidities of these materials. In this way, titration using Hammet indicators have been used but this technique is restricted to colorless solids. Infrared spectroscopy (IR) of adsorbed pyridine has also been used to determine the nature of the acid sites [9,10,13-16], but the fact that at low desorption temperatures (about 423 K) pyridine is completely desorbed, makes this technique unsuited to show the superacid character of these materials. Other methods such as electronic paramagnetic resonance (EPR) of adsorbed benzene [ 10,11 ] or temperature-pro- grammed desorption (TPD) studies using weak bases [ 17 ] have also been proposed in the determination of the acid strength of solids superacids. The aim of this paper is to study the influence of the preparation procedure of Zr( OH)4 on the final catalytic properties of SOl-/ZrOz catalysts, for the n-butane isomerization reaction. In addition to this, the differences obtained in the determi- nation of the acid strength of these catalysts using TPD of ammonia and pyridine adsorption, is also discussed. 2. Experimental 2.1. Catalyst preparation Hydrous zirconium oxides were obtained by hydrolysing ZrOC12.8H20 (Aldrich) in aqueous ammonia solution (25 wt.-% NH3) under vigorous stirring, at room temperature, reaching a determined pH between 6.0 and 9.4. Different times of precipitation were u sed ( 0.5, 1.0 and 8.0 h) and the corresponding hydrous zirconium oxides are referred as HZO-r, HZO and HZO-1, respectively. Then, the product was filtered and washed with deionized water until free of chlorine, and dried at 433 K overnight. Sulfated zirconia (SZ, SZ-r and SZ-1) catalysts were prepared by impregnation of the corresponding hydrous zirconium oxides, for 1 h, with a 0.5 M H2SO 4 solution (5 cm 3 of solution per 1 g of hydrous zirconium oxide), followed by filtration and drying at 433 K overnight. Finally, the solid was calcined in a stream of air (20 cm 3 min- 1), at 823 K for 3 h. For comparison, zirconium oxides (ZO, ZO-r and ZO-I series) were prepared from the corresponding hydrous zirconium oxides by calcination, in air, at 823 K for3 h. For identification, the HZO, ZO and SZ series are preceded by a number that indicates the pH of precipitation of the starting hydrous zirconium oxide. A. Corma et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 116 (1994) 151-163 In order to compare the acidity of the sulfated zirconia, with more conventional acid catalysts, H-mordenite was obtained from NHa-mordenite CBV20 (PQ) (Si/ A1 = 10) by calcination in air, at 773 K for 4 h. 2.2. Catalytic test The catalytic experiments were carded out in a quartz fixed-bed flow reactor at atmospheric pressure. Pure n-butane was fed with a contact time (W/F) of 39 gcath(molc4) -l, and the reaction temperature was 423 K. In previous experiments, it was found that at the flow (1.2 1 h-~) and catalyst particle size (0.42-0.59 mm) used in this study, the process was not controlled by either external or internal diffusion. The catalyst, when in the reactor, was calcined at 823 K during 3 h, and then the temperature was lowered until the reaction temperature was reached. After reaction, the catalysts were regenerated by calcination in air (20 cm 3 min- ~) at 673 K for 16 h. The products were analyzed at different times-on-stream, with an on-line gas chromatograph using a capillary column (50 m length, fused silica Plot A1203/ KC1. 2.3. Catalyst characterization The BET surface area of the samples, aBET, was obtained in an ASAP 2000 apparatus, following the BET method from nitrogen adsorption isotherms at 77 K and taken a value of 0.164 nm 2 for the cross-section of nitrogen. Thermogravimetric (TG) and differential thermal (DTA) analysis were carded out by means of a Nest instrument, using 0.2 mg of sample, a heating rate of 10 K min- ~, an air gas flow of 100 ml min- 1, over the 303-1073 K temperature range. The reference material was A1203 previously ignited at 1373 K. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected in a Philips 1060 diffracto- meter, equipped with a graphite monochromator, operated at 40 kV and 40 mA and using nickel-filtered Cu Kol radiation ()t = 0.1542 nm). Infrared spectra of adsorbed pyridine were obtained in a Nicolet 710 FTIR spectrophotometer. Wafers of 10 mg cm -2 were mounted in a pyrex vacuum cell fitted with CaF2 windows. The samples were pretreated at 673 K overnight and then cooled at room temperature (rt) to obtain the original IR spectra. Then, pyridine was admitted at room temperature, degassed at 373 K for one hour in order to remove the fraction physisorbed, and the spectra taken at room temperature. Pyridine was also desorbed at temperatures of 423, 523 and 673 K. Temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) experiments were carded out on a TPD/TPR 2900 apparatus from Micromeritics. 0.2 g of sample was pretreated in oxygen stream at 823 K for 3 h. Ammonia was adsorbed at 373 K until saturation of the sample and then desorbed at 373 K in order to A. Corma et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 116 (1994) 151-163 remove physisorbed ammonia. Then the temperature was increased up to 873 K in a helium stream ( 100 ml min- ~). The heating rate was 10 K min- ~ and the process was monitored by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). To avoid interferences with other possible desorption products (e.g. water from dehydroxylation of the sample) a blank run was performed for each sample following the same desorption programme but without previous adsorption of ammonia. 3. Results and discussion Fig. 1 shows the surface area of sulfated zirconia SZ-r samples as a function of the pH of precipitation of the parent hydrous zirconium oxides, HZO-r, obtained at a short times of hydrolysis. There, the surface area of the calcined zirconium oxide, ZO-r, samples is also given for comparison. It is apparent that the higher the pH of precipitation is, the higher is the surface area of the HZO-r, ZO-r, and SZ-r samples. Meanwhile, and in the whole pH range studied, the surface area of the samples decreased in the order HZO-r > SZ-r > ZO-r. Sulfate-doped zirconia samples obtained both at different pH and/or time of precipitation were compared. The surface area and the amount of sulfur of these samples are shown in Table 1. In general, it can be said that both time and pH of precipitation have an important influence on the surface area of sulfated zirconia catalysts. In addition to this, the same influence was observed with the correspond- ing zirconium oxides. From the structural point of view, the pH of precipitation has a clear influence on the crystalline phases of zirconium oxide formed on both ZO and SZ samples (Figs. 2 and 3). Indeed, for the ZO series, tetragonal (t) and monoclinic (m) ZrO2 mixtures were observed, and the t/m ratio varied with pH. In all cases the conversion (xa- %) was measured at different times-on-stream in order to be able to obtain the activity in absence of decay (see Fig. 6). Higher activities were obtained on SZ-samples prepared at high pH of precipitation. In all cases, the only product detected was isobutane. It should be remarked that only when the contact time was increased and n-butane conversion was higher than 25%, propane and pentanes were obtained as minor products. Propane is probably not formed by direct cracking since then equivalent amounts of methane should be observed, which was not the case. Under our reaction conditions, a strong catalyst decay is observed during the first 0.4 h of time-on-stream, and after this the activity becomes stable. The initial activity can be restored by calcining in air at 673 K during 16 h. From a comparative point of view, the catalytic results obtained on the 8.3-SZ sample and those on one of the most acidic zeolites [23 ], i.e., H-mordenite, are compared in Table 3. It can be seen there that at reaction temperatures below 523 K only the 8.3-SZ catalyst is active in the isomerization of n-butane. At higher reaction temperatures both samples show catalytic activity but a lower selectivity to isobutane is obtained on H-mordenite. According to these results it can be concluded that sulfated zirconia oxides present acid sites with superior strength than those of an H-Mordenite, and the former are strong enough to carry out the direct isomerization of n-butane to isobutane at relatively low temperatures. 3.2. Nature and strength of the acid sites It has been proposed that a correlation between the ratio of Brensted to Lewis acid sites and the catalytic activity of SO ]-/ZrO2 exists [9], while other authors [ 15,16] indicate that only Lewis acid sites are responsible for the catalytic prop- erties of these materials. More recently, it has been proposed [ 13,14] that the Brensted/Lewis ratio of acid sites depends on the preparation procedure, the hydration-dehydration degree and mainly the calcination temperature. To confirm this assumption we have performed pyridine adsorption/desorption experiments to measure the acidity (Brensted and Lewis) of the different SZ samples. Corma et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 116 (1994) 151-163 Infrared spectra of adsorbed pyridine, obtained at different desorption tempera- tures on the 8.3-SZ and H-mordenite samples are shown in Fig. 7. The results show that at any of the desorption temperatures studied, the intensity of the IR band of pyridine retained on Br0nsted ( 1545 cm- ~) and/or Lewis acid sites ( 1450 cm- t ) are much higher for H-mordenite than for 8.3-SZ sample. A straightforward inter- pretation of these results would indicate that both number and strength of the acid sites is higher on the zeolite than on the sulfated zirconium oxide. However, this interpretation is not consistent with the catalytic results presented above. Thus, one has to conclude that the pyridine adsorption--desorption is not the most adequate technique to show the superacid sites of sulfated zirconia catalysts. There are two reasons which can explain this observation. The first one is that the, probably, small number of the very strong acid sites present in the catalysts of the SZ-series does not show a signal intense enough to be detected by this technique. The second one is that pyridine decomposes if very high desorption temperatures are to be used in order to evidence the superacid sites [24]. Therefore, the only thing which can be safely concluded is, that the majority of acid centers in SZ catalysts are of the Lewis type, in agreement with ref. [ 15,16 ], and that the acid strength can not be properly determined by pyridine desorption experiments. Therefore, correlations between the nature and strength of acid sites, measured by pyridine adsorption and catalytic properties must be taken with care, in the case of sulfated zirconia catalysts. Temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia has been proposed as a meas- ure of total acidity and acid strength distribution in solids [25]. The NH3-TPD results for the SZ and the H-mordenite catalysts are shown in Figs. 8 and 9, respectively. For the SZ-series (Fig. 8) three desorption ranges can be differenti- ated: two broad peaks at 450 K and 590-620 K, and a narrow one at 815 K, all of them corresponding to ammonia desorbed as can be concluded from the comparison with the blank desorption curve (Fig. 8a). These peaks can be assigned to acid sites with strengths in the low (450 K) and medium-strong (ca. 600 K) range, as those present in a Y zeolite [ 26]. However the appearance of a relatively narrow peak at ca. 815 K whose intensity increases from b to e (Fig. 8) indicates the presence of very strong and homogeneous acid sites on SZ samples. For comparison, Fig. 9 shows the NH3-TPD curve of an strongly acidic H-mordenite (see pyridine adsorption results). It can be seen that the TPD curve corresponding to the true acid centers in H-mordenite shows two maxima corresponding to medium (ca. 517 K) and strong (748 K) acidity, but no desorption peak appears at higher temper- atures. All these results allowed us to conclude that TPD-NH3 desorption peak at ca. 815 K correspond to superacid sites present on SO4 =/ZrO2 samples. Fig. 10 shows that a correlation exists between the amount of superacid sites, measured from the intensity of the NH3-TPD peak at 815 K, and catalytic activity for isomerization of n-butane obtained at a time-on-stream of 5 min. The fact that a straight line is not observed in Fig. 10 ca be explained on the basis of the catalytic decay. In effect, as can be observed in Fig. 6, the catalyst decay is more important for the more active catalysts. A. Conclusions The pH of precipitation for obtaining Zr(OH)4 modifies the surface area and the tetragonal/monoclinic ratio of ZrO2 crystallites in both pure and sulfated zirconias, this effect being maximal on the SO4 2-/ZrO2 samples. Also, the pH of precipitation determines the activity of SO4 2-/ZrO2 catalysts for the isomerization of n-butane in such a way that a higher pH of precipitation produces more active catalysts. Infrared spectra of adsorption/desorption of pyridine can not be used to detect the presence of superacid sites in sulfated zirconia catalysts. However, the superacid character in these samples is evidenced by TPD-NH3 results in which the appearance of a desorption peak at about 815 K can be related with the presence of superacid sites. In this way, a correlation between the surface area of the desorption peak determined by TPD-NH3 and the catalytic properties for the isomerization of n- butane can be proposed. A. SO4 2−/ZrO2 samples were prepared by impregnation of hydrous zirconium oxides with 0.5M H2SO4 solutions. It was found that the pH of precipitation of the precursor Zr(OH)4 has a strong influence on the structure of crystalline ZrO2 and on the catalytic properties of the SO4 2−/ZrO2 for the isomerization of n-butane. The nature and strength of acid sites in SO4 2−/ZrO2; samples were studied by infrared spectra of absorbed pyridine and by temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of ammonia. Acidity and catalytic results have been compared with those obtained on an acid zeolite as H-Mordenite. However, the NH3-TPD technique shown that in the case of SO4 2−/ZrO2 samples there are superacid sites in which the NH3-desorption peak appears at about 815 K.
